author: Staff Reporter
text:
As part of Great Backyard Bird Count

As part of the four-day annual worldwide Great Backyard Bird Count (GBBC), students of The American College here have recorded the presence of 26 species of birds on their campus.

The GBBC was launched in 1998 as a project of Cornell Lab of Ornithology and National Audubon Society.

The exercise encourages citizens from all walks of life across the world to watch and record online the distribution and abundance of birds.

A press release from the college said that more than 50 students participated in this year’s GBBC that commenced from February 12.

The participating students did birding for two hours daily from morning 6 a.m. to 8 a.m.

Of the 26 species observed, the statement said that the most commonly seen were Rufous treepie, Spotted owlet, Coppersmith barbet, Shikra, Coucal, Roller, Black winged kite, Flame backed woodpecker and Paradise flycatcher.

The participating students did birding for two hours daily from 6 a.m.

to 8 a.m.
title: Students record 26 species of birds on college campus
